title: 113_hr1874
content: The "Pro-Growth Budgeting Act of 2014" may be cited as the short title. It amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to include a new section on macroeconomic impact analyses of major legislation. The Congressional Budget Office is required to prepare a macroeconomic impact analysis for major bills or resolutions reported by committees, excluding the Committee on Appropriations. The analysis covers a ten-year period and must be submitted to the committee along with the basis for the analysis. The Congressional Budget Office must provide an economic impact analysis for major bills or resolutions, detailing effects on GDP, business investment, employment, interest rates, and fiscal impacts. Various economic models should be used to capture potential outcomes, with details on models, data sources, and transformations provided for clarity. The Congressional Budget Office provides macroeconomic impact analyses for major bills or resolutions, estimating changes in economic output, employment, interest rates, capital stock, and tax revenues. After five years, reports on the accuracy of these analyses are submitted to the House and Senate Budget Committees. The Congressional Budget Office provides macroeconomic impact analyses for major bills or resolutions, estimating changes in economic output, employment, interest rates, capital stock, and tax revenues. The term 'major bill or resolution' refers to any bill with budgetary effects estimated to be greater than .25 percent of the current projected gross domestic product of the United States. The term 'budgetary effect' for a major bill includes changes in revenues, outlays, deficits, and debt resulting from the measure. The macroeconomic analysis described in subsection (c) shall rely on analysis prepared by the Joint Committee on Taxation for legislation with revenue provisions. The House of Representatives passed the macroeconomic impact analysis of major legislation on April 4, 2014.
